newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Meridian firms after Estate Mortgage deal.
newsitem.headline: Meridian firms after Estate Mortgage deal.

text.p: The units of Meridian Investment Trust rose at the opening on Monday after settlement of the Estate Mortgage legal dispute with Burns, Philp & Co Ltd.
Meridian was up eight cents at A$1.55, while Burns Philp was also a touch firmer, up one cent to A$2.45.
Volume was light for both stocks.
Analysts said the settlement was in line with market expectations of around A$100 million.
Under the deal Burns Philp will pay Meridian A$90 in cash and issue it with 12 million convertible notes at A$2.20 each.
Meridian, formerly the Estate Mortgage group, said the settlement would deliver the trusts a minimum value of A$116.4 milion.
Tyndall Australia Ltd, the manager of the trust, said the settlement would substantially strengthen its financial position.
Analysts said the settlement may have been spurred by a desire by Burns Philp to end the long-running dispute and focus on operational problems at the troubled herbs and spice group.
"It's very good news for Burns Philp," said BNP Equities analyst Helen Cameron. "I think it makes very good common sense to get it out of the way."
The settlement underpinned a A$2.50 share price, Cameron added.
New Zealand investor Graeme Hart last month took a 19.9 percent interest in Burns Philp, paying A$2.50 a share.
The acquisition surprised the market as it was well above Burns Philp's share price at the time.
Burns Philp subsidiary Burns Philp Trustee Co was the trustee for Estate Mortgage from 1983 until it went into liquidation in 1990, with debts of more than A$600 million.
Former Estate Mortgage auditors Priestley & Morris agreed to pay Meridian A$31 million in an out of court settlement in April this year.
